revisions.rev:
{{Infobox sports season | title = 2010â11 Pac-10 Men's Basketball Season |caption=#193980 | color =#193980 |color text =#FFFFFF | league = [[Division I (NCAA)|NCAA Division I]] | sport = [[College basketball|Basketball]] | logo = | pixels = | caption = | duration = | no_of_teams = 10 | attendance = | TV = | draft = | draft_link = | top_pick = | picked_by = | season = Regular Season | season_champs = [[2010â11 Arizona Wildcats men's basketball team|Arizona Wildcats]] | second_place = [[2010â11 UCLA Bruins men's basketball team|UCLA Bruins]] | MVP = | MVP_link = Pac-10 Conference Men's Basketball Player of the Year | top_scorer = | top_scorer_link = | finals = Tournament | finals_link = 2011 Pacific-10 Conference Men's Basketball Tournament | finals_champ = [[2010â11 Washington Huskies men's basketball team|Washington Huskies]] | finals_runner-up = [[2010â11 Arizona Wildcats men's basketball team|Arizona Wildcats]] | finals_MVP = | finals_MVP_link = Most Valuable Player | seasonslist = | seasonslistnames = Basketball | prevseason_link = 2009â10 Pacific-10 Conference men's basketball season | prevseason_year = 09â10 | nextseason_link = 2011â12 Pacific-12 Conference men's basketball season | nextseason_year = 11â12 }} {{2010â11 Pacific-10 Conference men's basketball standings}} The '''2010â11 Pacific-10 Conference men's basketball season''' began with practices on October 18, 2010 and ended with the [[2011 Pacific-10 Conference Men's Basketball Tournament]] from March 9â11, 2011 at the [[Staples Center]] in Los Angeles. The regular season began on the weekend of November 12, with the conference schedule starting on December 30. The conference dedicated the season to legendary [[UCLA Bruins men's basketball|UCLA]] coach [[John Wooden]], who died in June 2010 at age 99.<ref name=bolch>{{cite news |last=Bolch |first=Ben |title=Pacific 10 Conference dedicating basketball season to John Wooden |date=October 28, 2010 |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/sports_blog/2010/10/pacific-10-conference-dedicating-basketball-season-to-john-wooden.html |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xJXb8TiN |archivedate=March 19, 2011}}</ref>
The [[2010â11 Washington Huskies men's basketball team|Washington Huskies]] defeated the regular season champions [[2010â11 Arizona Wildcats men's basketball team|Arizona Wildcats]] 77â75 in overtime to capture the tournament championship. Four Pac-10 teams were selected to participate in the [[2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]]: Arizona, Washington, UCLA and USC.
This was the final season for the Pac-10 under that name. In July 2011, two schools [[2010 NCAA conference realignment#Pacific-10 Conference|will join]] the conference, at which time its name will officially change to Pacific-12 Conference. [[Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball|Colorado]] will arrive from the [[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] and [[Utah Utes men's basketball|Utah]] will enter from the [[Mountain West Conference|Mountain West]].
==Pre-season== * Pre-season media day was held on October 28, 2010 at [[L.A. Live]]'s [[Nokia Theatre]] in downtown Los Angeles. *[[Dana Altman]] was named the head coach of the [[Oregon Ducks]]. * 2010â11 PAC-10 Men's Basketball Media Poll:<ref>[http://www.uclabruins.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/102810aaa.html Preseason Pac-10 Media Poll], ''UCLABruins.com'', October 28, 2010</ref> :Rank, School (first-place votes), Points :1. Washington (33) 348 :2. Arizona (1) 296 :3. UCLA (1) 281 :4. Arizona State 215 :5. Washington State 191 :6. USC 178 :7. California 151 :8. Oregon State 120 :9. Stanford 98 :10. Oregon 47
==Rankings== {{main|2010â11 NCAA Division I men's basketball rankings}} * November 8, 2010 â Washington #17 (Coaches) * November 15, 2010 â Washington #17 (AP), #15 (Coaches) * November 22, 2010 â Washington #13 (AP), #11 (Coaches) * November 29, 2010 â Washington #23 (AP), #22 (Coaches) * December 6, 2010 â Washington #21 (AP), #22 (Coaches) * January 3, 2011 â Washington #23 (AP) * January 10, 2011 â Washington #17 (AP), #18 (Coaches)
==Non-Conference games== * November 24, 2010 â UCLA lost to No. 7 [[2010â11 Villanova Wildcats men's basketball team|Villanova]] at the semifinals of the [[NIT Season Tip-Off]]. * December 18, 2010 â UCLA upset No. 16 (AP) [[2010â11 BYU Cougars men's basketball team|BYU]] 86â79 at the [[John R. Wooden Classic]].
==Conference games== * December 29 â First conference games.
==Conference tournament==
{{main|2011 Pacific-10 Conference Men's Basketball Tournament}} * March 9â11, 2011 â Pac-10 Conference Basketball Tournament, [[Staples Center]], [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]].
==Head coaches== {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-2}} :[[Sean Miller]], Arizona :[[Herb Sendek]], Arizona State :[[Mike Montgomery]], California :[[Dana Altman]], Oregon :[[Craig Robinson (basketball)|Craig Robinson]], Oregon State {{col-2-of-2}} :[[Johnny Dawkins]], Stanford :[[Ben Howland]], UCLA :[[Kevin O'Neill]], USC :[[Lorenzo Romar]], Washington :[[Ken Bone]], Washington State {{col-end}}
==Post season== ===[[2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]]=== * March 15, 2011 â Tournament begins. * April 4, 2011 â National Championship game. * March 13, 2011 â Four Pac-10 teams were selected: Arizona ([[2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament#West Regional â Anaheim|West Region]]), Washington ([[2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament#East Regional â Newark|East Region]]), UCLA ([[2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament#Southeast Regional â New Orleans|Southeast Region]]) and USC ([[2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament#Southwest Regional â San Antonio|Southwest Region]]). * March 16, 2011 â USC ended its tournament hopes when they were defeated in the first round to VCU. * March 17, 2011 â UCLA defeated Michigan State to advance to the third round to face Florida on Saturday, March 19, 2011. * March 19, 2011 â UCLA was defeated by Florida 65â73 and ended its season. * March 20, 2011 â Arizona defeated Texas 70â69 to advance to the Sweet Sixteen and Washington was defeated by North Carolina 83â86 to end the season. * March 24, 2011 â Arizona defeated 1-seed Duke 93â77 in the Sweet Sixteen to advance to the Elite 8. * March 26, 2011 â Arizona was defeated by UConn 65â63 in the Elite 8.
===[[2011 National Invitation Tournament|NIT]]=== * March 13, 2011 â Two Pac-10 teams were selected to play in the NIT: California ([[2011 National Invitation Tournament#Colorado bracket|Colorado bracket]]), Washington State ([[2011 National Invitation Tournament#Boston College bracket|Boston College bracket]]).
===[[College Basketball Invitational|CBI]]===
==Highlights and notes== * November 12, 2010 â UCLA and Oregon kicked off the season with wins over San Diego State and North Dakota State respectively. * February 25, 2011 â California was placed on two years probation for impermissible recruiting phone calls.<ref>Associated Press, [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/news/story?id=6159315 Cal punished for impermissible calls], ESPN.com, February 25, 2011</ref> * February 26, 2011 â UCLA defeated Arizona in the final men's basketball game in [[Pauley Pavilion]] before the building goes into renovation for a year. The late Coach [[John Wooden]]'s great-grandson Tyler Trapani scored the last two points for the Bruins.<ref>{{cite news |last=Painter |first=Jill |url=http://m.dailynews.com/ladn/db_11049/contentdetail.htm;jsessionid=235728BEE34F9E0D590B3345C10F6FEE?contentguid=DD3L1E14&detailindex=8&pn=0&ps=10&full=true#display |title= Trapani's shot leaves lasting image at Pauley Pavilion |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Daily News]] |date=February 26, 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xJLlkeQu |archivedate=March 19, 2011}}</ref>
==Awards and honors== * The Pac-10 Coach of the Year Award in both menâs and womenâs basketball is now known as the [[John Wooden]] Coach of the Year Award.<ref name=bolch/>
